description: From Middle English question, questioun, questiun, from Anglo-Norman questiun, from Old French question, from Latin quaestiōnem, accusative of quaestiō (“a seeking, investigation, inquiry, question”), from quaerere (“to seek, ask, inquire”), of uncertain origin, but possibly from Proto-Italic *kʷaizeō, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷeh₂- (“to acquire”).
Displaced native Old English āscung. Compare also Middle Low German quēstie (“questioning; inquiry”), Middle High German questje (“question”).

entries.meaning: A sentence, phrase or word which asks for information, reply or response; an interrogative.
examples: Can I ask you two a question? / Please, Christ, yes. / How can you two live like this? / How can... / Don't google the question, Moss!

entries.meaning: A subject or topic for consideration or investigation.
examples: The question of seniority will be discussed at the meeting.
There was a question of which material to use.

entries.meaning: A doubt or challenge about the truth, accuracy, or validity of a matter.
examples: His claim to the property has come under question.
The story is true beyond question.

entries.meaning: A proposal to a meeting as a topic for deliberation.
examples: I move that the question be put to a vote.

entries.meaning: (now archaic, historical, chiefly with definite article) Interrogation by torture.

verbs.description: question (third-person singular simple present questions, present participle questioning, simple past and past participle questioned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To ask questions of; to interrogate; to ask for information.
(transitive) To raise doubts about; have doubts about.
examples:
He questioned South Korean claims that China is a major source of its pollution.
Audio (US)(file)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To ask a question or questions; inquire or seek to know; examine.
examples: He that questioneth much shall learn much.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To argue; to converse; to dispute.
